RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduao em Engenharia Civil pela Universidade Federal de Pernambuco (2006), e mestrado e doutorado em Economia pela University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (2011). Atualmente Professor do Departamento de Economia da Universidade Federal de Pernambuco. Seus interesses acadmicos incluem economia da educao, economia dos transportes, econometria aplicada e desenvolvimento econmico. Tem artigos publicados na American Journal of Agricultural Economics, Economics Letters, Empirical Economics, Journal of Regional Science, entre outros.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: bachelor's at Engenharia Civil from Universidade Federal de Pernambuco (2006), master's at Economics from University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (2011) and doctorate at Economia from University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (2011). , acting on the following subjects: transporte pblico, gesto dos transportes, cadeia produtiva, anlise de eficincia and emprego, renda e arrecadao.

GRADUACAO.NOME-AGENCIA: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cientfico e Tecnolgico

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES: Planejamento de Transportes / Departamento de Engenharia Civil
Planejamento Integrado dos Recursos Hdricos / Departamento de Engenharia Civil

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The Long-Term Effects of a Tuition-Free University on Crime
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: We investigate the effect of attending a top-quality institution on criminal charges. Using applications to a university in Brazil and criminal prosecution and employment records, we exploit a discontinuity in its admission process. Effects are found to vary by income group. If admitted, students from high-income families are mildly affected, while students from low-income backgrounds are much less likely to be prosecuted for violent crimes in the following decade. We show that educational attainment, financial distress, employment, and the college wage premium do not explain our findings. The most evident mechanism is the interaction with distinct socioeconomic groups. Our results suggest that promoting socioeconomic diversity in higher education has important returns at the individual and societal level.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Climate Adaptation Policies and Infant Health: Evidence from a Water Policy in Brazil
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This paper studies how in utero exposure to a large climate adaptation program affects birth outcomes. The program built around one million cisterns in Brazil's poorest and driest region to promote small-scale decentralized rainfall harvesting. Access to cisterns during early pregnancy increased birth weight, particularly for more educated women. Data suggest that more educated women complied more with the program's water disinfection training, highlighting that even simple, low-cost technologies require final users' compliance (``the last mile") to be effective. In the context of growing water scarcity, adaptation policies can foster neonatal health and thus have positive long-run implications.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Women Police Stations and Domestic Violence:The Role of Law Enforcement
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: We investigate impacts of women police stations on domestic violence using administrative data from Brazil. Importantly, we test whether a legislative reform affording increased protection to victimized women and tougher sentences for perpetrators enhanced their effectiveness. The evidence suggests an increase in reporting which initially leads to increased perpetration, but which translates into lower rates of perpetration after the legislative reform. Our results illustrate the perils of encouraging women to report domestic violence before appropriate safeguards are in place. At the same time it shows that if access to police reporting can be improved in concert with access to women's shelters and judicial reform, this can engender very large declines in domestic violence.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Do Relative Disadvantages in College Reinforce Women's Glass Ceiling?
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The underrepresentation of women in leadership roles is an enduring problem worldwide. It has motivated studies on the creation of mentoring programs and microenvironments in higher education. Still, experimental evidence on their long-term effects is limited. By applying a rigorous quasi-experimental method, we estimate the consequence of class composition in college on women's job promotion nearly ten years after they enter the institution. To do so, we combine administrative data from a flagship university in Brazil and employment records. In most of its programs, this university splits first-year students into two groups based on admission scores. Throughout the program, students in the same group take most of the courses together. The quasi-experiment consists of a regression discontinuity design, which compares the last student who joins the group with higher scores (the "first class") and the first student left out of this group, who joins the "second class." These students are virtually identical, and their GPA is not affected by the assigned group. However, in their first term, the grades of the first-class student are, on average, 0.22 standard deviations lower than his or her classmates'. Although the relative gap in grades is similar for both genders, only women's chances of a job promotion decrease if joining the better group. Thus, women's specific reactions to momentary disadvantages have long-term consequences for their careers. Despite the negative effect of having relatively better peers, this effect seems mitigated as the absolute quality of these peers increases.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The Effect of Job Loss and Unemployment Insurance on Crime in Brazil
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
We investigate the eect of job loss and unemployment benets on crime, exploiting unique
individual-level data on the universe of workers and criminal cases in Brazil over the 2009-2017
period. We nd that the probability of criminal prosecution increases on average by 23% for workers
displaced upon mass layos, and by slightly less for their cohabiting sons. Using causal forests, we
show that the eect is driven entirely by young and low tenure workers, who are more likely to be
liquidity constrained. Regression discontinuity estimates indicate that unemployment benet
eligibility completely osets potential crime increases upon job loss, especially for
liquidity-constrained individuals, although this eect completely vanishes upon benet expiration.
Our ndings point at liquidity constraints and psychological stress as main drivers of criminal
behavior upon job loss, while substitution between time on the job and leisure does not seem to play
an important role.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: On the Individual Determinants of Access to Justice: Evidence from Matched Labor and CourtData
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This paper investigates the role of contract termination and liquidity constraints on judicial litigation. We ask how these events affect ($i$) the likelihood that a plaintiff will bring a case, ($ii$) the probability that the case will end in settlement or sentence in favor of the plaintiff, and ($iii$) whether there is a learning effect regarding the use of the judicial system. We exploit a novel data-set that matches the universe of job spells in Brazil to the universe of labor and civil cases for the period 2010-2018 and then we apply two empirical approaches: event-study and regression discontinuity design.
